facts.text: Criminal Appeal No. 49 of 1956 was filed by special leave.

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Criminal Appeal No. 49 of 1956. Appeal by special leave from the judgment

facts.text: Appeal arises from judgment and order dated October 13, 1954 of Madras High Court in Criminal Revision Case No. 267 of 1954 and Criminal Revision Petition No. 249 of 1954.

anchor.surface_text: from the judgment and order dated October 13, 1954, of the Madras High Court in Criminal Revision Case No. 267 and 1954 1212  Criminal Revision Petition No. 249 of 1954

facts.text: High Court case arising out of judgment dated January 12, 1954 of District and Sessions Judge Tiruchirapalli in Criminal Revision Petition No. 17 of 1953.

anchor.surface_text: arising out of the judgment and order dated January 12, 1954, of the Court of the District and Sessions Judge as Tiruchirapalli in Criminal Revision Petition No. 17 of 1953.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on August 25, 1958 by SINHA J.

anchor.surface_text: 1958. August 25. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by SINHA J.-The only question for determination in this appeal

facts.text: Appellant filed petition of complaint against three respondents in court of Additional First-Class Magistrate, Tiruchirappalli.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that the appellant filed a petition of companyplaint in the companyrt of the Additional First-Class Magistrate, Tiruchirappalli, against the respondents, three in number.

facts.text: Petition of complaint dated June 5, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: On those allegations, the petition of companyplaint  dated June 5, 1953  prayed that processes might issue

facts.text: First accused is leader of Dravida Kazakam, a community professing to be religious reformers propagating against idol worship.

anchor.surface_text: The petition of companyplaint alleged inter alia that the first accused is the leader of Dravida Kazakam  a companymunity of persons who profess to be religious reformers, one of whose creeds is to carry on propaganda against idol worship

facts.text: First accused announced intention of breaking image of God Ganesa on 27th May 1953 in public meeting at Town Hall.

anchor.surface_text: It is further alleged in the petition of companyplaint that recently, the first accused announced his intention of breaking the image of God Ganesa, the God sacred to the Saiva Section of the Hindu Community on 27th May, 1953, in a public meeting at Town Hall.

facts.text: Announcement caused terror in minds of Saivite section of Hindu community; complainant is Saivite.

anchor.surface_text: This caused terror-commotion in the mind of the Saivite Section of the -Hindu Community. The companyplainant claims to be a Saivite.

facts.text: On May 27, 1953 at about 5:30 p.m., first accused broke idol of God Ganesa in public at Town Hall Maidan after making speech stating intention to insult feelings of Hindu community.

anchor.surface_text: The companyplainant further alleged in his petition that on May 27, 1953, at about 5-30 p.m., the accused broke an idol of God Ganesa in public at the Town Hall Maidan, and before breaking the idol, lie made a speech, and expressly stated that he intended to insult the feelings of the Hindu companymunity by breaking the idol of God 1213 Ganesa.

facts.text: Other two accused abetted by instigation and aid, also made speeches.

anchor.surface_text: The said act of breaking the idol was alleged to have been actively abetted by instigation and aid by the other two accused persons, who also made speeches.

facts.text: Act done with intention of insulting religious feelings of sections of Hindu community who venerate God Ganesa.

anchor.surface_text: The petition of companyplaint also alleged that the said act of breaking the image of God Ganesa was done with the intention of insulting the religious feelings of certain sections of the Hindu companymunity, who hold God Ganesa in veneration

facts.text: Magistrate examined complainant on oath on June 5, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: On the same date, the learned magistrate examined the companyplainant on oath. The companyplainant made statements in support of his allegations in the petition of companyplaint.

facts.text: Magistrate directed petition sent to Circle Inspector of Police, Trichy for inquiry and report under s.202 CrPC.

anchor.surface_text: Thereupon, the learned magistrate directed that the petition of companyplaint be sent to the Circle Inspector of police, Trichy, for inquiry and report under s. 202, Criminal Procedure Code.

facts.text: On June 26, 1953, police report received stating occurrence took place but point of law if offence.

anchor.surface_text: On June 26, 1953, on receipt of the police report which showed that though the occurrence as alleged had taken place it was a point of law if the act of the accused would amount to any offence

facts.text: Magistrate dismissed complaint under s.203 CrPC on June 26, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: , the learned magistrate passed his order, dismissing the companyplaint under s. 203 of the Criminal Procedure Code.

facts.text: Magistrate held mud figure of Ganesa not an object held sacred.

anchor.surface_text: In the companyrse of his order, the learned magistrate observed as follows- The mud figure of Ganesa alleged to have been broken by accused is number an object held sacred or worshipped by any class of persons.

facts.text: Complainant filed revision petition on July 9, 1953 to Sessions Judge Tiruchirapalli under ss.435 and 436 CrPC.

anchor.surface_text: The companyplainant moved the learned Sessions Judge of Tiruchirappalli, by his petition in revision, filed on July 9, 1953, under ss. 435 and 436 of the Criminal Procedure Code

facts.text: Revision confined to offence under s.295 IPC.

anchor.surface_text: In the petition filed in the Court of Session, the companyplainant stated that the petition was companyfined to the companyplaint in respect of the alleged offence under s. 295, Indian Penal Code

facts.text: Sessions Judge dismissed revision on January 12, 1954 holding no offence under s.295.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Sessions Judge dismissed the petition by an order dated January 12, 1954, holding, in agreement with the learned magistrate, that the acts companyplained of did number amount to an offence under s. 295, Indian Penal Code.

facts.text: Sessions Judge held image was private property of accused, not sacred.

anchor.surface_text: The accused, who profess to be religious reformers in a campaign against idolatory organized a public meeting at which they broke an earthern image of the God Ganesa. The particular image broken was the private property of the accused and was number in itself an object held sacred by any class of persons

facts.text: Complainant filed revision in Madras High Court under s.439 CrPC.

anchor.surface_text: The companyplainant then moved the High Court in its revisional jurisdiction under s. 439 of the Code of Criminal Procedure.

facts.text: High Court single Judge dismissed revision on October 13, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: The matter was heard by a learned single Judge of that Court. ... refused to order further inquiry.

facts.text: High Court held mud image of Ganesa not within s.295 as not sacred like idols in temples.

anchor.surface_text: The learned single Judge also agreed with the companyrts below ... Interpreted like that, it would mean that the section would apply only to cases where an idol in a temple is sought to be destroyed, damaged, or defiled.

facts.text: High Court refused certificate for appeal to Supreme Court under Art.134(1)(c).

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner moved the High Court for the necessary certificate of fitness for making an appeal to this Court. The learned Judge, who had heard the case on merits, also dealt with this application, and refused to certify that this was a fit case for appeal to this Court under Art. 134 1  c  of the Constitution.

facts.text: Supreme Court granted special leave to appeal.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner moved this Court and obtained the necessary special leave to appeal.

facts.text: No one appeared for respondents in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: Ganapathy Iyer and G. Gopalakrishnan, for the appellant. No one appeared for the respondents.

facts.text: Facts alleged in petition not controverted.

anchor.surface_text: In this case, the facts alleged in the petition, do number appear to have been companytroverted, but the learned magistrate, as also the learned Sessions Judge and the learned Judge in the High Court

facts.text: Image of Lord Ganesa held sacred by certain classes of Hindus even if not consecrated.

anchor.surface_text: Apart from the question of evidence, which had yet to be adduced, it is a well-knonwn fact that the image of Lord Ganesa or any objective representation of a similar kind, is held sacred by certain classes of Hindus, even though the image may number have been companysecrated.

facts.text: Supreme Court held lower courts erred in restricting meaning of s.295 IPC.

anchor.surface_text: As a result of these companysiderations, it must be held that the companyrts below have erred in their interpretation of the crucial words of s. 295 of the Indian Penal Code.

facts.text: Supreme Court did not direct further inquiry as case stale after about 5 years.

anchor.surface_text: But the question still remains whether, even after expressing our strong disagreement with the interpretation of the section by the companyrts below, this Court should direct a further inquiry into the companyplaint, which has stood dismissed for the last about 5  ,ears. ... we do number direct further inquiry into this companyplaint.
Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated October 13, 1954, of the Madras High Court
under Art. 134 1  c  of the Constitution.

arguments.claim: Intention alone insufficient unless act falls within s.295; dolls/images in homes not sacred

anchor.surface_text: Though the intention of the respondents may be to decry the feelings and wound the susceptibilities of a large section of the people, still the intention alone is number sufficient unless it is carried out by an act which must fall within the scope of this section. The dolls in the shop, though they may resemble several of the deities in the temple, cannot be held to be objects held sacred by any class of persons.

anchor.surface_text: and that the words have been used in their fullest amplitude by the Legislature, in order to include any object companysecrated or otherwise, which is held sacred by any class of persons, number necessarily belonging to a different religion or creed.

arguments.claim: Image of Lord Ganesa held sacred by certain classes of Hindus even if not consecrated (judicial notice)

anchor.surface_text: Apart from the question of evidence, which had yet to be adduced, it is a well-knonwn fact that the image of Lord Ganesa or any objective representation of a similar kind, is held sacred by certain classes of Hindus, even though the image may number have been companysecrated.

arguments.claim: s.295 not limited to idols in temples or processions; no express limitation

anchor.surface_text: The learned Judge in the Court below, has given much too restricted a meaning to the words any object held sacred by any class of persons , by holding that only idols in temples or idols carried in processions on festival occasions, are meant to be included within those words. There are numbersuch express words of limitation in s. 295

arguments.claim: Sacred books like Bible, Koran, Granth Saheb within ambit of s.295

anchor.surface_text: Idols are only illustrative of those words. A sacred book, like the Bible, or the Koran, or the Granth Saheb, is clearly within the ambit of those general words. If the companyrts below were right in their interpretation of the crucial words in s. 295, the burning or otherwise destroying or defiling such sacred books,

arguments.claim: Restricted interpretation against established canons of construction

anchor.surface_text: placing such a restricted interpretation on the words of such general import, is against all established canons of companystruction.

arguments.claim: Any trivial object held sacred falls within s.295; not necessary to have been worshipped

anchor.surface_text: Any object however trivial or destitute of real value in itself, if regarded as sacred by any class of persons would companye within the meaning of the penal section. Nor is it absolutely necessary that the object, in order 1218 to be held sacred, should have been actually worshipped.

arguments.claim: Courts must respect religious susceptibilities of different classes irrespective of beliefs' rationality

anchor.surface_text: It is clear, therefore, that the companyrts below were rather cynical in so lightly brushing aside the religious susceptibilities of that class of persons to which the companyplainant claims to belong. The section has been intended to respect the religious susceptibilities of persons of different religious persuasions or creeds.

arguments.claim: Lower courts erred in interpretation of s.295

anchor.surface_text: As a result of these companysiderations, it must be held that the companyrts below have erred in their interpretation of the crucial words of s. 295 of the Indian Penal Code.

arguments.claim: No further inquiry as case stale after 5 years

anchor.surface_text: But the question still remains whether, even after expressing our strong disagreement with the interpretation of the section by the companyrts below, this Court should direct a further inquiry into the companyplaint, which has stood dismissed for the last about 5  ,ears. ... we do number direct further inquiry into this companyplaint.

holdings.text: The courts below have erred in their interpretation of the crucial words of s. 295 of the Indian Penal Code

anchor.surface_text: As a result of these considerations, it must be held that the courts below have erred in their interpretation of the crucial words of s. 295 of the Indian Penal Code.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Lower courts restricted 'any object held sacred' to consecrated temple idols using ejusdem generis and analogies; Supreme Court rejects as no express limitation, words in full amplitude include sacred books like Bible/Koran/Granth Saheb, trivial objects not worshipped; against canons of construction; depends on evidence if held sacred; respect religious susceptibilities irrespective of rationality

holdings.text: The words 'any object held sacred by any class of persons' in s. 295 IPC include any object consecrated or otherwise held sacred, even trivial or not actually worshipped, illustrated by sacred books like the Bible, Koran or Granth Saheb; not limited to idols in temples or processions

anchor.surface_text: the words of s. 295, particularly, the words any object held sacred by any class of persons, and that the words have been used in their fullest amplitude by the Legislature, in order to include any object consecrated or otherwise, which is held sacred by any class of persons, not necessarily belonging to a different religion or creed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual analysis rejects ejusdem generis limitation to places of worship; no express words restricting to consecrated idols; purposive to protect religious feelings; analogy to sacred books; judicial notice of Ganesa images; evidence determines if held sacred

holdings.text: Whether any object is held sacred by any class of persons must depend upon the evidence in the case

anchor.surface_text: In the first place, whether any object is held sacred by any class of persons, must depend upon the evidence in the case... In this case, the facts alleged in the petition, do not appear to have been controverted,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Facts in complaint not controverted; dismissal at s.203 stage improper without evidence on whether object held sacred

holdings.text: It is a well-known fact that the image of Lord Ganesa or any objective representation of a similar kind, is held sacred by certain classes of Hindus, even though the image may not have been consecrated

anchor.surface_text: Apart from the question of evidence, which had yet to be adduced, it is a well-known fact that the image of Lord Ganesa or any objective representation of a similar kind, is held sacred by certain classes of Hindus, even though the image may not have been consecrated.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Judicial notice of common knowledge regarding Hindu beliefs

holdings.text: This Court does not direct a further inquiry into the complaint

anchor.surface_text: But the question still remains whether, even after expressing our strong disagreement with the interpretation of the section by the courts below, this Court should direct a further inquiry into the complaint, which has stood dismissed for the last about 5 years. ... we do not direct further inquiry into this complaint.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Strong disagreement with lower courts but case stale after 5 years; action foolish if true but no utility in proceeding

Revision powers under Sections 435/436 CrPC concern directing further inquiry into complaints, directly addressing the issue of whether this Court should direct further inquiry
